articles.name: Executive Reports Overview
articles.title: Executive Reports Overview
articles.body:
On the Executive Reports tab, you can add, resize, and rearrange widgets to create custom executive reports. The widgets allow you to display your organization’s phishing, training, and Risk Score metrics. You can also add supporting titles, subtitles, text, and tables. The reports can then be printed as a PDF file or scheduled to be printed later.

Note: Data from your KSAT console can take up to 24 hours to process and display in your executive reports.

System Executive Report Templates

The Executive Reports tab includes three system report templates. For more information about these reports, see below:

  • Security Admin Report: This report template includes information such as your organization’s training completion, Risk Score trend, Phish-prone Percentage, and Phishing Security Test (PST) results.
  • CISO Report: This report template includes information such as your organization’s Risk Score trend, risk score, training completion, training status, PST results, and Phish-prone Percentage.
  • Team Manager Report: This report template includes information such as the Risk Score, training completion, PST results, and Phish-prone Percentage for each of your manager’s teams.

To view these report templates, click the drop-down menu in the top-left corner of the Executive Reports tab and then select the report you want to view. While you're unable to change the system report templates, you can still make edits and then save your changes under a new report name.

Executive Reports Widgets

You can customize your executive reports using widgets. Click the tabs below to learn about the widgets that you can add to your executive reports.

The Title and Logo widget allows you to add titles, subtitles, and your company logo to your report.

To learn how to customize this widget, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Show Logo: Select this check box to display your company logo. To learn how to add your company logo, see our How to Add Your Company Logo, Logo URL, and Brand Color to Your Console article.
  2. Executive Report Templates: Use this drop-down menu to add a template.
  3. Body: Enter any text that you’d like in our What You See is What You Get (WYSIWYG) editor.

Click Apply Changes to save your changes to the widget.

The Training Metrics widget allows you to add a training activity graph or table to your report. To learn how to customize this widget, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Override selected report settings for Group, Start Date, and End Date: Enable this setting to set the Timeline field for the widget instead of using the default report settings.
  2. Value Type: Use this drop-down menu to select the value type you would like to view for your selected criteria. For example, you can view the total time spent on training or the percentage of completed training.
    Note:The Total Count option refers to the total count of training module assignments for each user.
  3. Category: Use this drop-down menu to select the category you would like to view data for. For example, you can view data for training campaigns or departments.
  4. Grouped By: Use this drop-down menu to select how you would like to group data for your selected category. For example, you can group data by email address for each department.
  5. User Groups: Use this drop-down menu to select one or more groups that you would like to include in your graph or table.
  6. Title: Enter a title for your graph or table.
  7. Chart Type: Use this drop-down menu to select how you would like to display your data.
    • When using a table, you'll find two more options under Additional Filters:
      • Show totals for Category selection: Use this filter to calculate a total for the variable selected from the Category drop-down menu.
      • Show totals for Grouped By selection: Use this filter to calculate the total for the variable selected from the Grouped By drop-down menu.
    • If the value type includes percentages, the total is displayed as a weighted average. This weighted average considers multiple factors, such as how many pieces of content are in a training campaign or how many users have received a specific Phishing Security Test. If you filter by Group, enabling Show totals for Category selection or Show totals for Grouped By selection can result in double counting.
      Note: We use weighted averages because a simple average could be misleading. Simple averages treat all percentages the same, regardless of the number of users in a campaign. The weighted average considers the number of users involved and more accurately represents the information.
  8. Include Archived Users: Enable this setting to include archived users in your graph or table.
  9. Include items with blank values: Enable this setting to display items with blank values for your selected criteria. For example, this setting could allow users without a value in the Department field to display.
  10. Include Trend Line: Enable this setting to display a linear trend line over your line graph, showing the overall direction of data. This option is only available for line graphs.
  11. Top Results: Use this drop-down menu to display only the top 5, 10, or 100 results for your selected criteria. All results are displayed by default.
  12. Date Interval: Use this drop-down menu to select the date range you would like to group your data by.
  13. Training Additional Criteria: Use this drop-down menu to select additional criteria for the Training Campaigns drop-down menu below. You can select Campaign Training, Optional Learning, or AIDA Optional Learning.
  14. Training Campaigns: Use this drop-down menu to select one or more campaigns to include in this report.
  15. Timeframe: Select a start and end date for your executive report.

Click Apply Changes to save your changes to the widget.

The Phishing Metrics widget allows you to add a phishing activity graph or table to your report. To learn how to customize this widget, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Override selected report settings for Group, Start Date, and End Date: Enable this setting to set the Timeframe field for the widget instead of using the default report settings.
  2. Value Type: Use this drop-down menu to select the value type you would like to view for your selected criteria. For example, you can view the Phish-prone Percentage or the percentage of reported PSTs in a phishing campaign.
  3. Category: Use this drop-down menu to select the category you would like to view data for. For example, you can view data for phishing campaigns or departments.
    • The Detailed Phishing Test Result category displays the types of phishing failures and the number of times those failures occurred.
    • The Phish Failure Type category displays the most severe phishing failure.
  4. Grouped By: Use this drop-down menu to select how you would like to group data for your selected category. For example, you can group data by email address or PST failure type.
  5. User Groups: Use this drop-down menu to select one or more groups that you would like to include in your graph or table.
  6. Title: Enter a title for your graph or table.
  7. Chart Type: Use this drop-down menu to select how you would like to display your data.
    • When using a table, you'll find two more options under Additional Filters:
      • Show totals for Category selection: Use this filter to calculate a total for the variable selected from the Category drop-down menu.
      • Show totals for Grouped By selection: Use this filter to calculate the total for the variable selected from the Grouped By drop-down menu.
    • If the value type includes percentages, the total is displayed as a weighted average. This weighted average considers multiple factors, such as how many pieces of content are in a training campaign or how many users have received a specific Phishing Security Test. If you filter by Group, enabling Show totals for Category selection or Show totals for Grouped By selection can result in double counting.
      Note: We use weighted averages because a simple average could be misleading. Simple averages treat all percentages the same, regardless of the number of users in a campaign. The weighted average considers the number of users involved and more accurately represents the information.
  8. Include Archived Users: Enable this setting to include archived users in your graph or table.
  9. Include items with blank values: Enable this setting to display items with blank values for your selected criteria. For example, this setting could allow users without a value in the Department field to display.
  10. Include Trend Line: Enable this setting to display a linear trend line over your line graph, showing the overall direction of data. This option is only available for line graphs.
  11. Top Results: Use this drop-down menu to display only the top 5, 10, or 100 results for your selected criteria. All results are displayed by default.
  12. Date Interval: Use this drop-down menu to select the date range you would like to group your data by.
  13. Timeframe: Select a start and end date for your executive report.

Click Apply Changes to save your changes to the widget.

The Risk Score Trend widget allows you to add a Risk Score data graph or table to your report. To learn how to customize this widget, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Override selected report settings for Group, Start Date, and End Date: Enable this setting to set the Timeframe field for the widget instead of using the default report settings.
  2. Value Type: By default, Risk Score is automatically selected. For more information about Risk Score, see our Smart Risk Agent and Risk Score Guide.
  3. Category: Use this drop-down menu to select the category you would like to view data for.
  4. Grouped By: Use this drop-down menu to select how you would like to group data for your selected category. For example, you can group data by organization.
  5. User Groups: Use this drop-down menu to select one or more groups that you would like to include in your graph or table.
  6. Title: Enter a title for your graph or table.
  7. Chart Type: Use this drop-down menu to select how you would like to display your data.
  8. Include Archived Users: Enable this setting to include archived users in your graph or table.
  9. Include items with blank values: Enable this setting to display items with blank values for your selected criteria. For example, this setting could allow users without a value in the Department field to display.
  10. Include Trend Line: Enable this setting to display a linear trend line over your line graph, showing the overall direction of data. This option is only available for line graphs.
  11. Top Results: Use this drop-down menu to display only the top 5, 10, or 100 results for your selected criteria. All results are displayed by default.
  12. Date Interval: Use this drop-down menu to select the date range you would like to group your data by.
  13. Timeframe: Select a start and end date for your executive report.

Click Apply Changes to save your changes to the widget.

The Text Block widget allows you to add text, tables, and templates to your report.

To learn how to customize this widget, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Executive Report Templates: Use this drop-down menu to select a template. You can then customize the template to fit your needs. For more information about the templates, see the list below:
    • Title: Use this template to add a title, subtitle, and company logo. You can also use this template to add a custom logo to your text.
    • Recommendations: Use this template to add a list of recommendations for building a security awareness program.
    • Risk Score Key Metrics: Use this template to show the key performance indicators for your organization’s Risk Score.
    • Training Completion Key Metrics: Use this template to show your key performance indicators for your organization’s training completions.
    • Phishing Key Metrics: Use this template to show your key performance indicators for your organization’s phishing data.
    • Key Metrics Summary: Use this template to show the key performance indicators related to your organization’s Risk Score, training completions, and phishing data.
  2. Key Metrics Placeholders: Use these placeholders to customize the key metrics templates to fit your organization's needs. For more information about each placeholder, see our Key Metrics Information Placeholders Guide.
  3. Body: Enter any text that you would like in our What You See is What You Get (WYSIWYG) editor.
  4. Show Logo: Select this check box to display your company logo. To learn how to add your company logo, see our Add Your Company Logo, Logo URL, and Brand Color to Your Console article.

Click Apply Changes to save your changes to the widget.

The PAB Activities widget allows you to add information regarding the Phish Alert Button (PAB) to your report.

Note:The PAB Activities widget includes simulated data from hidden phishing campaigns.

To learn how to customize this widget, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Override selected report settings for Group, Start Date, and End Date: Enable this setting to set the Timeframe field for the widget instead of using the default report settings.
  2. Add Filter: Click this button to add more filters for your PAB widget.
  3. Value Type: Use this drop-down menu to select the value type you would like to view for your selected criteria.
    Note:The Total Count value type includes all PAB reports, including repeated ones.
  4. Category: Use this drop-down menu to select the category you would like to view data for. 
  5. Grouped By: Use this drop-down menu to select how you would like to group data for your selected category. For example, you can group data by email address for each department.
  6. Title: Enter a title for your graph or table.
  7. Chart Type: Use this drop-down menu to select how you would like to display your data.
    • When using a table, you'll find two more options under Additional Filters:
      • Show totals for Category selection: Use this filter to calculate a total for the variable selected from the Category drop-down menu.
      • Show totals for Grouped By selection: Use this filter to calculate the total for the variable selected from the Grouped By drop-down menu.
        If the value type includes percentages, the total is displayed as a weighted average. This weighted average considers multiple factors, such as how many pieces of content are in a training campaign or how many users have received a specific Phishing Security Test. If you filter by Group, enabling Show totals for Category selection or Show totals for Grouped By selection can result in double counting.
        Note: We use weighted averages because a simple average could be misleading. Simple averages treat all percentages the same, regardless of the number of users in a campaign. The weighted average considers the number of users involved and more accurately represents the information.
  8. Include Archived Users: Enable this setting to include archived users in your graph or table.
  9. Include items with blank values: Enable this setting to display items with blank values for your selected criteria. For example, this setting could allow users without a value in the Department field to display in the widget.
  10. Top Results: Use this drop-down menu to display only the top 5, 10, or 100 results for your selected criteria. All results are displayed by default.
  11. Timeframe: Select a timeframe for your widget.

Click Apply Changes to save your changes to the widget.

Creating Executive Reports

To create an executive report, you can create a new report or clone an existing custom report. For more information, see the subsections below.

Creating New Reports

To create a new report, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT account and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-right corner of the page, click Create Report > New Report.

  3. In the Report’s Name field, enter a name for your report.

  4. Add at least one widget to your report. You can add as many widgets as you would like to customize your report. For more information, see the Adding Widgets section below.
  5. (Optional) Set your report settings. For more information, see the Report Settings section below.
  6. Click Save Changes in the top-right corner of the page.

Cloning Reports

To clone an existing custom report, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT account and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report that you would like to clone.

  3. In the top-right corner of the page, click Create Report > Clone Report.

  4. Enter a name for your new report.

  5. Click Save Changes in the top-right corner of the page.
  6. (Optional) Edit the report as needed. For more information, see the Customizing Executive Reports section below.

Customizing Executive Reports

You can add, remove, resize, and rearrange widgets to create custom executive reports. For more information, see the subsections below. 

Report Settings

You can select report settings that will apply to all widgets on your report. To select your report settings, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT account and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report that you would like to edit.

  3. Click Edit Report.

  4. For more information about the report settings, see the screenshot and list below:

    1. Font: Use this drop-down menu to select a font to use for the report.
    2. Font Size: Use this drop-down menu to select a font size to use for the report.
    3. Text Color: Use this drop-down menu to select a text color to use for the report.
    4. PDF Layout: Use this drop-down menu to select the layout of your report when generating a PDF file. You can select from the two options below:
      • Select Manual to preview the PDF files and manually adjust the widget layout. These PDF files will be in portrait orientation. For more information, see the Previewing Reports section below.
      • Select Automatic to generate PDF files with your current widget layout. These PDF files will be in landscape orientation.
    5. User Groups: Use this drop-down menu to select the user groups to include in this report.
    6. Organization Chart: Use this drop-down menu to search by user name or job title. This filter shows user data for all organization levels under the selected users or job titles. For example, you can search for a specific job title, such as Director or VP. You can also select from the two additional settings below:
      • Select Include All Team Members to include the direct and indirect reports of the selected managers in the report.
      • Select Include Selected Manager to include the selected manager in the report. This check box will aggregate the data of the selected manager and any selected team member in the report.
    7. Date Range: Use this drop-down menu to select a date range for the report.
  5. Click Save Changes in the top-right corner of the page.

Adding Widgets

You can add widgets to customize your report. Because the widgets are customizable, you can add the same widget to the report as many times as you would like.

To add a widget to your report, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT account and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report that you would like to edit.

  3. Click Edit Report.

  4. Select a widget to add to your report. For more information about the widgets, see the Executive Reports Widgets section above.

  5. Click Save Changes in the top-right corner of the page.

Editing Widgets

You can edit widgets on your report. To edit a widget on your report, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report that you would like to edit.

  3. Click Edit Report.

  4. Hover your mouse over a widget until you see the crossed arrow icon.
  5. In the top-right corner of the widget that you would like to edit, click the gear icon.

  6. In the Customize Widget pop-up window that opens, edit the widget settings as needed. For more information about the widgets, see the Executive Reports Widgets section above.
  7. Click Apply Changes in the bottom-right corner of the pop-up window.

Removing Widgets

You can remove widgets from your report. To remove a widget from your report, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report that you would like to edit.

  3. Click Edit Report.

  4. Hover your mouse over a widget until you see the crossed arrow icon.
  5. In the top-right corner of the widget that you would like to remove, click the x icon.

Resizing Widgets

You can adjust the sizes of widgets to emphasize specific widgets, fit widgets next to each other, or organize widgets in a way that helps you understand your organization’s data.

To resize a widget in your report, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report you would like to edit.

  3. Click Edit Report.

  4. Click and drag inwards, outwards, upwards, or downwards until the widget is your preferred size.

  5. Click Save Changes in the top-right corner of the page.

Rearranging Widgets

You can rearrange widgets on your report to display them in any order you would like. To rearrange a widget on your report, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report you would like to edit.

  3. Click Edit Report.

  4. Hover your mouse over a widget until you see the crossed arrow icon.
  5. Click and drag the widget in any direction until the widget is at your preferred location.

Setting a Default Executive Report

You can set a default executive report. By default, this report will display when you access the Executive Reports tab. For example, if you have a report that you view daily and another report that you view monthly, you can set the report that you view daily as the default report to save time.

To set a default report, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report that you would like to set as your default report.

  3. Select Set as Default.

Downloading Executive Reports

You can generate PDF files of your executive reports to download and print. By default, you have the option to preview the PDF files and manually adjust the layout of the widgets. But you also have the option to use your current widget layout instead. For more information, see the subsections below.

Previewing Reports

You can preview a report and make changes before generating a PDF file. To preview a report, follow the steps below:

Note: The Preview PDF button will only display if the Manual option is selected for the PDF Layout report setting. For more information, see the Report Settings section above.
  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. Create a new report or edit an existing report.
  3. Click Preview PDF to see how your report will look as a PDF file.

  4. (Optional) Make any needed changes to your report. For example, you can resize widgets to fit on one page instead of being divided across two pages.

     

  5. Click Preview PDF to exit the preview.
  6. If you made any changes, click Save Changes.

Generating PDF Files

To generate a PDF file, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report that you would like to download.

  3. In the top-right corner of the page, click Print to generate the PDF file.

In the top-right corner of your console, a notification bell will display when the report that you generated is ready to be downloaded. Your generated report can also be downloaded from the Download Center at any time. For more information, see the Download Center Overview.

Downloading Widgets

To download an individual widget, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. Open the report whose widgets you would like to download.
  3. Navigate to the widget you would like to download, then click the three-lines icon in the top-right corner of the widget.

  4. Select how you would like to download your executive report widget.
Note:Widgets with Table selected as the Chart Type can't be downloaded. For information about this setting, see the Training Metrics tab in the Executive Reports Widgets section above.

Sending and Scheduling Executive Reports

You can send executive reports to other users. You can also schedule executive reports to be generated and sent at a frequency, such as every month. For example, you may want to schedule a report to be sent to your executive team every month to keep them updated on your security awareness program.

To generate executive reports on a schedule, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report that you would like to schedule to be sent.

  3. In the top-right corner of the page, click Schedule Report.

  4. Fill out the fields on the New Scheduled Report page and click Submit. For more information about these fields, see our How to Save and Send Reports article.

Deleting Executive Reports

You can permanently delete executive reports that you no longer need. To delete an executive report, follow the steps below:

Important: Once you delete a report, this action cannot be undone.
  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to Reports > Executive Reports.
  2. In the top-left corner of the page, select the report that you would like to delete.

  3. Click Edit Report.

  4. Click Delete Report.

articles.name: Cylance Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.title: Cylance Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.body:
In this article, you will learn how to integrate Cylance's endpoint protection platform (EPP) with SecurityCoach. Once you set up this integration, data provided by Cylance will be available under the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns. For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Important:To configure the Cylance integration, you'll need access to a CylancePROTECT Administrator account.

Copy Your Organization Key

Before you can set up this integration in your CylancePROTECT platform, you will need to authorize the configuration and copy your organization key from the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. You will need this key in the Set Up the Integration in Your CylancePROTECT Platform section below.To locate and copy your organization key, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  2. Locate Cylance and click Configure.
  3. Click Authorize. 
  4. In the pop-up window that opens, click OK.
  5. In the Organization Key field, copy your key. 

Set Up the Integration in Your CylancePROTECT Platform

Before you can set up this integration in your CylancePROTECT platform, you will need to authorize the configuration and copy your organization key from the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console.To set up the integration in your KSAT console, follow the steps below:

  1.  Log in to your CylancePROTECT platform, and navigate to Settings > Application.
    Important:You will need to log in as a user with an Administrator role.
  2. Scroll down to the Integrations section of the page.
  3. Select the Syslog/SIEM check box. Selecting this check box will prompt Cylance to stream events to SecurityCoach.
  4. Fill out the remaining fields. For more information, see the screenshot and list below:
    1. Event Types: Select all check boxes except for the >Audit Log check box.
    2. SIEM: Leave this field blank.
    3. Protocol: From the drop-down menu, select the protocol that you prefer.
    4. TLS/SSL: Leave this check box unchecked to disable TLS/SSL.
      Note:This field will only display if you selected TCP in the Protocol field.
    5. IP/Domain: Enter the domain for your KnowBe4 instance into the field. To find the domain for your KnowBe4 instance, see the table below:
      KnowBe4 Instance Domain
      United States syslog.training.knowbe4.com
      European Union syslog.eu.knowbe4.com
      Canada syslog.ca.knowbe4.com
      Germany syslog.de.knowbe4.com
      United Kingdom syslog.uk.knowbe4.com
    6. Port: Enter "4514" into the field.
    7. Severity: From the drop-down menu, select Notice (5).
    8. Facility: From the drop-down menu, select Internal (5).
    9. Custom Token: Enter "org_key=x,vendor_code_name=cylance,log_type=endpoint", but replace "x" with your organization key. 
  5. Click Test Connection to confirm that Cylance is able to connect to SecurityCoach.
  6. Click SAVE.

Map Your Users

After you’ve finished integrating Cylance, you can map your users either through mapping rules (recommended) or through a CSV file upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Mapping Users in SecurityCoach article.

Once you’ve successfully completed this integration, you can manage detection rules for Cylance on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.

Delete the Integration in Your CylancePROTECT Platform

To delete the Cylance integration from your SecurityCoach platform, follow the steps below.

  1. Log in to your CylancePROTECT platform.
  2. Click the gear icon, and then click Application.
  3. Scroll down to the Integrations section of the page.
  4. Deselect the Syslog/SIEM check box.

articles.name: User Messaging Guide
articles.title: User Messaging Guide
articles.body:
The User Messaging feature allows you to send messages to some or all of your users within the KSAT console. Once a message has been created, the Messages tab of the Learner Experience (LX) will be enabled. On this tab, users can review and mark their messages as read. If no messages have been created, the Messages tab will remain hidden. For more information about the Messages tab, see our Learner Experience Guide.

User messaging can be used to send custom messages, such as informative memos or announcements. You can also use this feature to share our KnowBe4 messages: the Scam of the Week and Security Hints and Tips.

Custom Messages

Custom Messages are one-time messages that you can customize with our What You See Is What You Get (WYSIWYG) editor. You can use custom messages for internal memos, frequently asked questions (FAQs), announcements, and more.

Scam of the Week Messages

The Scam of the Week is a weekly message written by KnowBe4. The message summarizes a recent real-world scam and provides tips on how to stay safe from similar scams. You can create a recurring Scam of the Week message.

For more information on how to set up a Scam of the Week message, see our Scam of the Week Overview article.

Security Hints and Tips Messages

The Security Hints and Tips message is written by KnowBe4 and provides hints and tips for a wide variety of cybersecurity topics. A new message is added to the collection each month. You can create a recurring Security Hints and Tips message.

For more information on how to set up a Security Hints and Tips message, see our Security Hints and Tips Overview article.

Create New Messages

To create a custom message, follow the steps below:

  1. From your KnowBe4 console, navigate to Users > Messages.
  2. Click the +Create New Message button at the top-right corner of the page.
  3. Fill out all of the fields on the Create New Custom Message page. For more information about each field, see the screenshot and list below:

    1. Message Type: The message type can be a new custom template, a custom template you already created, a Scam of the Week template, or a Security Hints and Tips template.
    2. Frequency: Select how frequently the message template will be sent.
    3. Send to: Select All Users if you would like to send the message to your entire organization. Otherwise, select Specific Groups and choose one or more groups from the drop-down menu.
    4. Language: Select the written language for this message. You will need to provide the translated text for the message, unless it is a Scam of the Week or Security Hints and Tips message. The KnowBe4 console does not translate custom messages for you.
    5. Message Delivery Date: In this field, select when you would like to send your message.
      Note:When choosing Monthly as your Frequency, every message will automatically send on the first business week of the month. For example, if you select Thursday, July 24th, 2025, each message will be sent on the first Thursday of each month, not the 24th. Similarly, when choosing Quarterly as your Frequency, every message will automatically send on the first business week of each quarter.
    6. Also send this message as an email: Select this check box to send a copy of this message to each user via email. This message will still be listed on the Messages tab of the LX.
      Note:The sender's email address for User Messaging emails is do-not-reply@knowbe4.com.
    7. Use Custom Sender Information: Enable this option to customize the sender's name and email address. The email address must match one of the allowed domains on your account.
    8. Subject: The message subject will be seen by both users and admins.
    9. Message: Enter your message into the text field. Our WYSIWYG editor includes standard text formatting options such as font size, text alignment, and bullets. You can also use more advanced options such as images, hyperlinks, and div containers. To identify each option, hover your mouse over the WYSIWYG buttons. If you would rather edit this message using HTML, click the Source button to switch from the WYSIWYG editor to a source code view.
  4. Review each field and the contents of your message.
    Important: Scheduled custom messages can be edited before future deliveries, but you can’t edit messages that have already been sent.
  5. Click Schedule Message.
    Important: Emails sent using the User Messaging feature are not tracked and will not be included in any message-related data.

Managing User Messages

To view and manage your user messages, navigate to the Users > Messages. On the Messages subtab, you'll see the Message History table, which lists all messages sent within the last 90 days.

For more information about the Message History table, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Filter: You can click the Message Type drop-down menu to filter this table by the message types: Custom Message, Scam of the Week, and Security Hints and Tips. You can also use the Search field to search for keywords in the message subjects.
  2. Message History Table: This table is organized by the newest to oldest message and provides detailed information for each message. These details include the groups the message was sent to, the admin who sent the message, and the percentage of users who have marked the message as read in the Learner Experience (LX).
  3. Message Subject: Click the message subject to view the Overview and Users tabs for that message. See the Individual Messages section of this article for more information.
  4. Hide from Users: You can't delete user messages, but you can hide individual messages by clicking the Hide from Users toggle. The message will still appear in your admin console, but it will be hidden in the LX.
    • For messages that have been hidden, you can click the Show to Users toggle to unhide the message in the LX.
  5. Error Messages: Users and groups are subject to change. Any relevant changes to the Groups or Sender of a message will result in an error message in the corresponding column.

Individual Messages

When viewing your Message History, you can click on the subject of an individual message to view the Overview and Users tabs for that message.

The Overview tab includes a preview of the message and lists details such as the percentage of users who have marked the message as read in the Learner Experience (LX).

The Users tab includes a list of all the users who received the message and one of the following message statuses:

  • Created: The message has been created but is in the process of being sent to the user.
  • Delivered: The message has been sent to the user, and the user has logged in to the LX but has not marked the message as read.
  • Read: The message has been marked as read in the LX. Users with this status will also have a date in the Marked as Read column of the Users tab.

At the top of the page, you can filter the user list by message status or search for a specific user by their name or email address.

Scheduled Messages

The Scheduled Messages page lists all of your messages that you scheduled to send at a later date. Once your custom message is sent, you can view it in the Message History table.

For more information about the Scheduled Messages page, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Subject: Click on the subject of a message to be taken to the Edit Message page, where you can make changes to your message.
  2. Groups: Click on the groups of a message to edit which groups the message is sent to.
  3. Status: This column shows the status of each message. Messages will have the Scheduled status until they’re sent.
  4. Frequency: This column will show how often and when messages are sent.
  5. Send On: This column shows the specific dates messages will be sent on.
  6. Actions: Click the three dots icon underneath Actions to activate or deactivate the message being scheduled to send.

articles.name: KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) Console Integrations
articles.title: KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) Console Integrations
articles.body:
Below is a list of some of our integrations for KSAT. If you do not see the integration you are looking for, visit our API documentation to learn more about our API's capabilities. For more information on integrations for our other products, see our Phish Alert Button Integrations and PhishER Integrations articles.

Note:These integrations are with third parties. We recommend contacting the third party if you need further help with an integration.
Note:iPaaS (Integration Platform as a Service) integrations are available for the KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) console. These integrations enable KSAT customers to connect with various vendors and establish the ideal integration flow. The iPaaS integrations utilize KnowBe4’s Graph APIs to enable automated security awareness training workflows and data management in areas including groups, users, phishing, and training. For more information, see our Integrate with KSAT Using iPaaS Connectors article.
  • Adlumin is a security detection and response platform built to discover threats and IT operations needs in real-time. KnowBe4 integrates with Adlumin to send KSAT phishing and training data to Adlumin's Proactive Defense Program. With this integration, you can view phishing, training, and Risk Score reports directly from your Adlumin platform. For more information, see our How to Integrate Adlumin with Your KSAT Console article.
  • anecdotes is a compliance management platform. This integration allows you to send phishing, training, and user data from your KnowBe4 console to your anecdotes platform to automate and manage your compliance program. For more information, see our Integrate anecdotes with Your KnowBe4 Console article.
  • Anzenna is an AI-powered, agentless security platform that predicts and prevents insider threats before they cause a breach. This integration with KnowBe4’s KSAT console allows you to send Phishing Security Test (PST) data for additional security recommendations. For more information, see Anzenna’s Onboarding Anzenna: Connecting KnowBe4 article.

  • A-SCEND is a compliance automation solution from A-LIGN that monitors and collects training completions for compliance requirements. This integration allows you to send training data from your KSAT console to A-SCEND for your compliance needs.For more information, see our How to Integrate A-LIGN with Your KSAT Console article.

  • Cisco’s Duo is an identity security solutions platform that specializes in multi-factor authentication (MFA) and zero trust security. This SCIM integration allows you to sync and manage your Duo users within your KSAT console. For more information how to integrate Duo with KSAT, see the Configure Automated Provisioning documentation from Duo and our SCIM Configuration Guide.
  • CloudEagle is an AI-powered platform that helps finance, operations, and IT teams streamline the management and renewal of software-as-a-service (SaaS) apps. You can integrate your Asana on the CloudEagle platform into your KSAT console. Integrating these apps with KSAT allows you to access detailed information about organizations, view user lists, manage user accounts, and monitor accurate usage of the Asana platform through user login activity. For more information, see our Integrate Asana on CloudEagle into Your KSAT Console article. 

  • COZYROC SSIS+ is a platform that allows you to migrate data from one place to another. This integration allows you to send campaign and user data from your KSAT console into the COZYROC platform.For more information, see our Integrating COZYROC SSIS+ with Your KSAT Console article.

  • CnSight is a cybersecurity performance management software. This integration allows you to send phishing data from your KSAT console to your CnSight platform to provide a broader view of your organization’s cybersecurity performance.For more information, see our How to Integrate CnSight with your KSAT Console article.
  • ControlMap is a cybersecurity compliance automation platform that monitors and collects evidence. This integration allows you to automatically mark training requirements as complete when your users complete their assigned KSAT training.For more information, see our How to Integrate ControlMap with Your KSAT Console article.
  • Cortex XSOAR is a SOAR platform that automates security operations and incident response. This integration allows you to use the KSAT pack so you can push and pull data to and from your KSAT console. To learn about the benefits of this integration, see our Cortex XSOAR and KnowBe4 document.For more information, see our How to Integrate Cortex XSOAR with Your KSAT Console article.
  • Cortex XSIAM is a service integration and management (SIAM) platform that helps to address and resolve security threats more efficiently. This integration allows you to use the KSAT pack so you can push and pull data to and from your KSAT console. For more information, see Cortex's KnowBe4 integration documentation.
  • CYE’s Hyver is a Cyber Risk Quantification Platform that allows you to create findings based on data from phishing simulation outcomes and compliance gaps discovered during KnowBe4’s security awareness training in your organization. For more information, see our Integrate CYE’s Hyver with Your KSAT Console article.
  • Cypago is a compliance platform that automates the process of preparing for compliance audits. This integration allows you to send KSAT training and user data to Cypago to show that your users are meeting compliance requirements.For more information, see our How to Integrate Cypago with Your KSAT Console article.
  • Cyren Inbox Security is a cloud-based, Internet security technology company that provides security as a service and threat intelligence services to businesses.Cyren Inbox Security establishes a new layer of automated security to detect and remediate phishing, business email compromise (BEC), and malware threats that have penetrated existing defenses and reached the user mailbox.For more information, see our Cyren Inbox Security (CIS) Integration article.
  • Databee is a risk and compliance platform from Comcast. This integration allows you to send phishing information from KSAT to Databee to get risk insights within your organization. For more information, see the KnowBe4 integration documentation from Databee.
  • Drata is a security and compliance automation platform that monitors and collects evidence when your personnel complete their assigned security awareness training. This integration can help you monitor your training results and compliance status for security audits.For more information, see our How to Integrate Drata with Your KSAT Console article and the Drata article Drata Integrations.
  • D3 Security is a security operations management software that provides tools and integrations for security automation, analysis, and incident response. D3 Security’s XGEN SOAR platform connects D3 Security’s playbook engine to external systems to exchange data and trigger system actions. This integration allows you to streamline data analysis and automate manual functions in your KSAT console. You can also use this integration to send data back to your KSAT console to change attributes, such as your users' Risk Scores.For more information, see our How to Integrate D3 Security with Your KSAT Console article.
  • Egress is a cloud-based email security platform that assesses human risk to help you prepare for phishing attacks and data breaches before they happen. With this integration, you can send your KSAT data to Egress to better prepare for cybersecurity attacks.For more information, see Egress’s KnowBe4 integration documentation.
  • ENGAIZ' ComplySec360™ is an information and security compliance platform that helps startups and small and medium enterprises improve their risk posture and helps with continued compliance with SOC 2, ISO 27001, GDPR, HIPAA, and more. For more information, see the Integrate ENGAIZ ComplySec360™ with Your KSAT Console article in our Knowledge Base.
  • Gradient MSP is a managed billing reconciliation service that enables partners to synchronize the latest active user counts from their KnowBe4 customer accounts, ensuring accurate billing based on the actual number of active users rather than the originally ordered seat count. For more information, see Gradient’s Overview and Configuration Guide: Integrating KnowBe4 KSAT with Gradient article.
  • Harmonic Security is a data security platform that allows new workflows for security awareness training. For example, you can use Tines’ webhooks to build workflows that allow users to resolve their own security issues in Harmonic Security’s user intervention features. For more information, see our Integrating Harmonic Security with KSAT Using Tines article.
  • Hyperproof is a cloud-based security and compliance automation platform that monitors and collects evidence. This integration can help you monitor your KSAT training results and compliance status for security audits.For more information, see the Hyperproof article Connecting to KnowBe4 and creating a Hypersync.
  • JupiterOne (J1) is a cloud-native security platform that connects across your siloed security tools, empowering unobstructed visibility into security risks across your entire cyber asset universe. This platform connects the dots between complex relationships and data, providing ultimate visibility to your environment, infrastructure, and operations.For more information, see the JupiterOne (J1) article KnowBe4 Integration with JupiterOne.
  • KCM GRC is a KnowBe4 platform that you can use to centralize your compliance and risk management efforts. This integration allows you to create automated KCM GRC tasks that collect training completion data from your KSAT platform. This data will automatically be uploaded as evidence for tasks so you can demonstrate how your organization is meeting its training requirements.For more information, see our How to Integrate KnowBe4's KSAT Console with KCM GRC article.
  • Liongard is a controls-monitoring platform that helps you continuously manage security posture across your IT stack and more. This integration allows you to monitor phishing tests, security awareness campaigns, and users to keep risks under control.For more information, see Liongard’s KnowBe4 integration documentation.
  • Mirage is an AI-driven social engineering platform that allows you to protect your organization through vishing (voice phishing) simulations, training, and mobile-based mitigation. You can sync Mirage simulation events directly into your KSAT console for reporting, training, and targeting purposes. For more information, see our Integrate Mirage with Your KSAT Console article.
  • MobileMind is a professional learning hub for schools. With this integration, you can send KnowBe4 training data to your MobileMind platform to provide a centralized place for tracking KnowBe4 courses. For more information, see the KnowBe4 integration setup from MobileMind.
  • Noetic Cyber is a cyber asset management and control platform that allows you to optimize your cybersecurity posture. This integration allows you to pull your phishing and training data into Noetic Cyber’s Security Asset Management platform. For more information, see our Integrate Noetic Cyber with Your KnowBe4 Console article.
  • Okta is a cloud-based identity and access management (IAM) platform that connects your apps, logins, and devices into one place. With this integration, you use the KnowBe4 Reporting API to pull data into Okta. For more information, see Okta’s KnowBe4 connector documentation.
  • Onyxia is a cybersecurity management platform that allows you to evaluate and organize your cybersecurity program. With this integration, you can send training information from KSAT to Onyxia to get strategic cybersecurity program recommendations. For more information, see our Integrate Onyxia with your KnowBe4 Console article.
  • Red Vector’s Fulcrum is an intelligence platform designed to enhance insider risk management. Integrating Fulcrum with KSAT can help you identify possible workplace threats earlier by performing risk analysis. This integration also allows you to assign training campaigns to reduce workplace risks. For more information, see our Integrate Red Vector’s Fulcrum with Your KSAT Console article.
  • SCIM (System for Cross-domain Identity Management) is an integration by KnowBe4 that allows you to leverage user data from your identity provider to provision, meaning to populate and maintain, your users within your KnowBe4 Console. For more information about SCIM, see our SCIM Configuration Guide. For more information about our supported providers, see the following articles:
    • How to Configure SCIM for Okta
    • How to Configure SCIM for Azure
    • How to Configure SCIM for OneLogin
    • How to Configure SCIM for JumpCloud
    • How to Configure SCIM for Rippling
    • How to Configure SCIM for PingFederate and PingOne
    • How to Configure SCIM for CyberArk Identity
  • Secureframe is a security and compliance software that helps automate the compliance process. This integration allows you to send training data from your KSAT console to your Secureframe account to help automate your organization’s compliance process.For more information, see our How to Integrate Secureframe with Your KSAT Console article.
  • SeeMetrics is a cybersecurity performance management platform that provides metrics and data visualization to its customers. KnowBe4 integrates with SeeMetrics to display your KSAT and PhishER data on their platform.For more information, see our How to Integrate SeeMetrics with Your KSAT Console article.
  • Seemplicity is a Remediation Operations (RemOps) platform that accelerates risk reduction and streamlines security compliance workflows. It helps organizations manage and automate remediation efforts across multiple teams, improving efficiency, effectiveness, and speed. Integrating with KSAT allows you to receive findings about training completion status via the Seemplicity platform. For more information, see our Integrate Seemplicity with Your KSAT Console article.
  • ServiceNow is an automation platform. With this integration, you’ll get detailed information about your organization's phishing preparedness.For more information, see ServiceNow’s KnowBe4 Integration for SecOps article.
  • Sprinto is a compliance automation platform that tracks training campaigns from KnowBe4 to help you monitor onboarding and periodic security training across your organization. Integrating with KSAT allows Sprinto to automatically update training completion statuses based on real-time campaign data, which reduces manual effort and ensures you have audit-ready evidence. For more information, see our Integrate Sprinto with Your KSAT Console article.
  • Swimlane is a security operations management software that provides workflow tools, such as automated incident response. Their SOAR platform streams your incident response process by integrating your people, processes, and technology.For more information, see Swimlane's integration documentation.
  • Tidal Cyber is a threat-informed defense platform that allows organizations to efficiently assess, organize, and optimize their cyber defenses based on a deep understanding of the threats and adversaries that are most relevant to them. Phishing Security Test (PST) activity can also be integrated into your Tidal Cyber platform. For more information, see our Integrate Tidal Cyber into Your KSAT Console article.
  • Tines is an automation platform that makes it easy for you to offload any of your monotonous workflows, giving you back time to increase your impact. You can connect to any REST API or web application in seconds.For more information, see our How to Add Training Notifications to Slack with the Tines Integration article.
  • Trustero is an AI-driven Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) platform that allows you to better collect evidence for more robust reporting. It has a pre-built integration with KnowBe4’s security awareness training. For more information, see our Integrating Trustero with KSAT article.
  • Truto is a unified API platform. KnowBe4 integrates with Truto to allow easy access to our APIs. With this integration, you can set up and perform specific actions between KnowBe4 and other applications using the Truto Unified API. see the KnowBe4 API integration and KnowBe4 SCIM API integration articles from Truto.
  • Vanta is a security compliance automation company that seeks to improve an organization’s security monitoring and significantly reduce the required time to prepare for security audits.For more information, see our How to Integrate Vanta with Your KSAT Console article and the Vanta article Connecting Vanta & KnowBe4.
  • Workato is a workflow automation platform that allows organizations to connect to both cloud and on-premise applications. This integration allows you to build automated workflows with KSAT’s API.For more information, see Workato’s KnowBe4 integrations and automation article.
  • XM Cyber provides cloud security that helps organizations identify and fix security exposures in their networks. Its Security Control Monitoring (SCM) module provides you with insights into the configuration and activation of security controls. For more information, see our Integrating XM Cyber’s SCM with KSAT article.

articles.name: Integrate Tines with PhishER
articles.title: Integrate Tines with PhishER
articles.body:
You can use webhooks to integrate your Tines platform with PhishER. The Tines platform allows you to connect to a REST API or web application and automate your workflows.

With this integration, you can use webhooks to send information from your PhishER console to your Tines platform. For example, you can configure webhooks to notify your Tines platform when a user reports an email using the Phish Alert Button (PAB). You can also configure webhooks to send automatic notifications from a SOAR platform to a communication tool, such as Slack. By using this integration, you can simplify workflows and save time for your organization. For general information about using webhooks in PhishER, visit our Create and Manage Webhooks in Your PhishER Platform article.

Creating Webhooks in Your PhishER Platform

Before you can set up this integration, you'll need to create a webhook in your PhishER console. To create a webhook, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your PhishER console.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Webhook.
  3. Click the New Webhook button in the top-right corner of the page to open the Add Webhook Settings page.
  4. Fill out the fields on the Add Webhook Settings page. For more information about our recommended settings, see the screenshot and list below:
    1. Name: In this field, enter a meaningful name for your webhook. This name will help your admins recognize the purpose of the webhook.
    2. URL: In this field, enter the callback URL for your webhook.
      Note: If you want to rewrite or shorten the URL, we recommend using one of our compatible rewriters or shorteners. For a list of compatible options, visit our FAQ: PhishER article.
    3. Authorization: From this drop-down menu, select one of the following protocols: No Auth, API Key, Bearer Token, or Basic Auth. We recommend keeping the default setting, which is No Auth.
    4. Available Data: Select one or more types of data that you would like to send to the webhook. We recommend that you select the Raw, Links, Tags, PhishML, and Attachments check boxes.
    5. (Optional) Custom Data: If you want to add custom data to your webhook’s payload, click the plus sign icon. Then, fill out the key and value fields.
    6. (Optional) Custom Headers: If you want to add a custom header, click the plus sign icon. Then, fill out the key and value fields.
    7. Message Tags: We recommend that you select the Success and Failure check boxes if you would like PhishER to assign a tag when the webhook is used to send data. Enter "WEBHOOK_SUCCESS" in the field next to the Success check box. Then, enter "WEBHOOK_FAILURE" in the field next to the Failure check box.
  5. Click Create.

After you create the webhook, you can create a PhishER action and select the Send to Webhook option. This option allows PhishER to send the reported messages that are affected by that action to your organization’s webhook.

Connecting to Your Tines Platform

Once you have created a webhook in PhishER, you will need to create an external workflow for the webhook. The steps for creating a workflow will vary depending on the action you want to perform, such as connecting PhishER to Slack using Tines. Example steps for connecting PhishER to Slack are listed below.

  1. Create an ingestion point to parse the Webhook payload.
  2. Unpack the EML contents from the presigned S3 URL.
  3. Run intelligence on email domains, IP addresses, and links. You can use third party and internal threat intel to run the intelligence.
  4. Navigate to your Slack workspace and build a custom Slack app using the manifest file template below.
    Tip:You can click the image below to view a text file of the manifest text file in a new tab.

  1. Copy the Webhook URL from your Slack workspace to point to the Slack channel of your choice.

  1. Use Slack's Block Kit to create your Slack notification. For an example, see the screenshot below.
    Tip:You can click the image below to view a text file of the manifest text file in a new tab.

  1. Send the Intel to your Slack App via HTTPs POST Call.
  2. POST Slack Message and the message will be posted to the Slack channel.

Tines Story Example

You can use the .txt file below as a starting point to connecting PhishER to your Tines platform. Once you access the manifest file by clicking the image, you can import the story to the Tines group of your choosing.

Tip:You can click the image below to view a text file of the manifest text file in a new tab.

For further assistance with this integration, contact our support team.

articles.name: Enable SAML Single Sign-on (SSO) for SecureAuth
articles.title: Enable SAML Single Sign-on (SSO) for SecureAuth
articles.body:
Below are the instructions for configuring single sign-on with SecureAuth. If you run into issues enabling SAML through SecureAuth, we recommend reaching out to SecureAuth for specific instructions. You can also contact our support team whenever you need assistance.

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account and click your email address in the top right corner.
  2. From the drop-down menu, select Account Settings.
  3. Navigate to the SAML section and expand the SAML Settings tab.
  4. Copy your unique SSO Callback (ACS) URL.
  5. In a new tab or window, open the SecureAuth Admin Console and navigate to the Post Auth tab within your KnowBe4 realm.
    Note: For more information on creating your KnowBe4 realm, see SecureAuth's Work with SecureAuth IdP realms article.
  6. Paste your SSO Callback (ACS) URL that you copied in Step 4 into the Assertion Consumer Service field of our Post Auth tab.
  7. Return to your KnowBe4 account settings and copy your SSO Sign-in URL.
  8. In your SecureAuth Post Auth tab, paste your SSO Sign-in URL in the SP Stat field.
  9. Then, scroll down to the Domain section and enter your identity service provider’s URL. For example, https://secureauth.example.com.
  10. Click Metadata File: Download. You will need the information in this file to complete your SAML setup through the KnowBe4 console. Follow the instructions in our Set Up SAML Single Sign-on (SSO) for the Security Awareness Training Console article to finish setting up SAML.
    Note: Make sure the email address that your users use to authenticate with SAML is either entered into the Email or Email Aliases field of their User Profile. However, only the email address listed in the Email field will receive training notification emails. For more information about adding information to user profiles, see our User Profile Guide.

articles.name: Identify and Address False Positives
articles.title: Identify and Address False Positives
articles.body:
If you are running a phishing campaign and see results that are unusual, you may be experiencing false clicks. When reviewing campaign results, if you see a 100 percent click rate or IP addresses that don't belong to your organization, this can be an indication of false positives. Below are some of the common reasons for false positives as well as some tips for handling them.

What Is Considered a Click?

Clicks are what we track when a user clicks on a phishing link in a simulated email. However, there are other ways a click may be registered. We refer to clicks that were not caused by a user clicking a phishing link as false positives. Listed below are some common reasons for false positives:

  • Improper whitelisting of your spam filter. Improper whitelisting can cause automated clicks or bot clicks. To learn how to tell if your click was a bot click, please see our How to Identify Bot Clicks section below.
  • Additional whitelisting may be required. Your spam filter may require additional whitelisting in order to exempt simulated phishing emails from link analysis or link probing.
  • Mail filters with security add-on packs that have not been whitelisted.
  • Endpoint security or antivirus software.
  • Link preview functions as part of mobile device operating systems.
  • Security software that is incorporated into mobile device management (MDM) systems.
  • Phishing emails that are forwarded from one user to another user. This action may be registered as a click because the forwarded email was sandboxed and checked by the mail server or because the recipient of the forwarded email clicked on the link.

How to Identify Bot Clicks

Instances of improper or insufficient whitelisting can lead to a bot click. Bot clicks are caused by an automated process within your infrastructure. You can identify a bot click by examining your phishing campaign results. Listed below are some ways you can identify bot clicks:

  • The times listed in the Delivered, Open, and Click columns are all the same or are within a minute of each other.
  • The Clicked tab indicates the browser or browser version is one that is not used in your environment or is outdated.
  • The operating system listed is one that your users don’t have access to in your environment.
  • The IP address belongs to a provider of one of your security products.

Unexpected IP Addresses in Campaign Results

When a click is registered in the console, the IP address is registered from where the click originated. Below are some examples of why you may see unexpected IP addresses:

  • If a user is on a mobile device and clicks on the link, the click could show as coming from the cellular service provider.
  • If a user is on the Wi-Fi in their house, the click would register as being from an IP address from that internet service provider (ISP).
  • If a user is on public Wi-Fi, the click would register from the location of where the user was when they clicked.
  • If you or one of your products uses a hosted services provider, such as AWS, the IP address may come from another location or even another country. Certain link analysis processes may not occur on the client side, and the link may be passed to the security provider’s backend processing or analysis center.
  • If the URL is sent to VirusTotal, the IP address may come from another location. This link may be sent automatically by a product you use or by your user. When a URL is submitted to VirusTotal, they analyze the URL to determine if it needs to be added to their threat definitions as hostile. Sometimes, this link analysis is instant. Other times, it may happen over the course of several hours. These IP addresses may register as a security vendor or they may register as an ISP.

Common Causes of False Positives

False positives in phishing simulations typically stem from three main sources:

  • Link scanner interference: Security tools that automatically select links before users see emails
  • Inadequate whitelisting: KnowBe4 domains are not properly exempted from security scanning
  • Misconfigured security policies: Spam filters or mail flow rules that conflict with phishing test delivery

To minimize false positives, configure your spam filters to exclude KnowBe4 phishing emails from link analysis and probing. Ensure smart hosts and advanced delivery policies align with your campaign configurations. When investigating link scanner-related issues, review your whitelisting settings with IT admins to strike a balance between security requirements and accurate training metrics.

How to Prevent False Positives

Knowing your infrastructure is the most important step for preventing false positives. Since there are a wide variety of security software products, you may want to check the documentation of the software or service providers that you use to see if there is a section about exempting links or domains from link scanning, link analysis, or link probing.

You can also run test campaigns with a couple of different templates on machines that would have the same setup as your users' workstations. These test campaigns can help you see if your current setup will cause false positives.

Make sure your users are only reporting emails via the Phish Alert Button and not your mail server's phishing button or any other third-party reporting feature.

Check to see if your security products have the option of additional whitelisting. If you can, whitelist our phish link domains and our landing page domains. This extra step can help prevent false positives. To see a list of our root phishing domains, navigate to the Phishing tab in your KnowBe4 console and select the Domains subtab. For more information on the Domains subtab, see our How to Manage Phish Link Domains article.

If you are still experiencing issues with false positives, contact our support team and they will be happy to assist you.

articles.name: How to Use the Documents Tab
articles.title: How to Use the Documents Tab
articles.body:
The Documents tab of your KCM GRC platform is a central repository of all of the documents, files, or links that have been added or uploaded to your account. This page contains files and links from your Compliance Management module, Policy Management module, and Vendor Risk Management module. 

Tip: Your auditors can see the files and links that are in the Documents tab in a limited capacity. For more information, see our Guide for Auditors article.

See the sections below to learn how to view files and links from the subtabs of the Documents tab.

Note: You will not be able to open links to local files by clicking the file name or link icon. Instead, you will need to right-click the file name and copy the link address. Then, open a new window in your browser and paste the link into the address bar.

All Documents

When you navigate to the Documents tab, you'll be taken to the All subtab.

To learn about this page, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Name: This column displays the name that the user assigned to the file or link when they added it to your platform. For vendor documents, this column displays the same name as the file that was attached to a questionnaire.
    Tip: If you hover over the name, you can see the URL for links and the extension for files.
  2. Date Created: This column displays the date that the file or link was added to your platform. 
  3. Actions: This column displays the following icons:
    1. If the item is a link, this column will show the link icon. Click this icon to open the web page in a new browser tab.
    2. If the item is a file, this column will show the download icon. Click this icon to download and view the file.

Evidence

The Evidence subtab is a repository of supporting evidence that your users have provided for the controls that you've implemented in your account. Users submit evidence to the platform by uploading a file or by providing a link to externally-hosted evidence. To learn more about submitting evidence, see our How to Monitor and Complete Tasks article.

To learn about this page, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Right arrow icon: Clicking on this icon expands the row and see any requirements that are applicable to the evidence item. Expand the following menu for more information.
      • If a requirement is applicable to an evidence item, this means that the evidence was submitted to a task for a control that is mapped to the requirement.
      • The expanded row will show the following information for the applicable requirements:
        1. Requirement ID: This column displays an ID that determines the order of requirements within a scope.
        2. Requirement Name: This column displays the name assigned to the requirement.
        3. Requirement Description: This column displays a description of the requirement.
  2. Name: This column displays the name that the user assigned to the evidence item when they added it to your platform.
    Tip: If you hover over a name you can see the URL for links and the extension for files.
  3. Control Name: This column displays the name of the control that is associated with the evidence item. You can click on the control name to open the control. 
  4. Task: Click a Task button in this column to open the control task that the evidence was submitted under.
  5. Date Created: This column displays the date that the evidence item was added to your platform.
  6. Actions: This column displays the following icons:
    1. If the evidence item is a link, this column will show the link icon. You can click this icon to open the web page in a new browser tab.
    2. If the evidence item is a file, this column will show the download icon. You can click this icon to download and view the file.
    3. You can click the pencil icon to update the evidence.
      Note: The pencil icon will not be available if the associated task is closed. Once a task is closed you cannot update the task evidence.

Policies 

The Policies subtab contains the internal policies, terms, or agreements that you have added to your platform for the purpose of user acknowledgment. Users add policies to the platform by uploading a file or by providing a link to an externally-hosted policy. For more information about the Policy Management module, see our Policy Management Module Guide.

To learn about this page, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Name: This column displays the name that the user assigned to the policy item when they added it to your platform.
    Tip: If you hover over a name you can see the URL for links and the extension for files.
  2. Version: This column displays the version that the user assigned to the policy item when they added it to your platform.
  3. Campaigns: This column displays the name of the campaign that you have created for users to acknowledge the policy. If the policy is assigned under multiple campaigns, the policy item is listed multiple times on this page. 
  4. Last Updated: This column displays the date that the policy item was last updated. 
  5. Actions: This column will display the following icons:
    1. If the item is a link, this column will show the link icon. You can click this icon to open the web page in a new browser tab.
    2. If the item is a file, this column will show the download icon. You can click this icon to download and view the file.
    3. You can click the pencil icon to update the policy item.

Vendor Documents

The Vendor Documents subtab contains files that your vendors or other third parties have attached to a questionnaire that you have assigned to them.

To learn about this page, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Name: This column displays the name of the file that a vendor user has attached to a question in a questionnaire. 
  2. Vendor: This column displays the name of the vendor profile that has attached the file to a questionnaire.  
  3. Questionnaire: This column displays the name of the questionnaire that the file was attached to. 
  4. Date Created: This column displays the date that the file was attached to the questionnaire. 
  5. Actions: This column will display the following icons:
    1. If the item is a file, this column will show the cloud icon. You can click the cloud icon to download and view the file.
    2. You can click the pencil icon to update the file.
    3. You can click the trashcan icon to delete the file.

Control Documents

The Control Documents subtab contains the files or links that you have added to your controls as a control document. Control documents can be used as an example of the evidence needed to satisfy a control. For more information on control documents, please see our Glossary of Compliance Terms article. To learn about this page, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Name: This column displays the name that the user assigned to the item when they added it to your platform.
    Tip: If you hover over a name you can see the URL for links and the extension for files.
  2. Control: This column displays the name of the control that the item was added to. 
  3. Date Created: This column displays the date that the item was added to your platform.
  4. Actions: This column will display the following icons:
    1. If the item is a file, this column will show the cloud icon. You can click the cloud icon to download and view the file.
    2. If the item is a link, this column will show the link icon. You can click the link icon to open the web page in a new browser tab.
    3. You can click the pencil icon to update the item.
    4. You can click the trashcan icon to delete the item.
